Comment: 1. Because the government borrows the money to pay out student loans by issuing bonds (currently at about 4.5% interest), so if the student loans aren't covering at least that level of interest, then the government is losing money. 2. Because inflation is a thing, so if I give you $10,000 today and you pay me back $10,000 in 10 years, that $10,000 I get back isn't worth as much. 3. Because not everybody pays their student loans in full. Quite a few people are paying $0 because their income is low enough that they're allowed to pay nothing on an income-based repayment plan. If some people are paying exactly what they borrowed while others never pay what they owe, then the government is losing money across all student loans. 4. Because there are costs associated with administering the student loan program. The government contracts with private loan servicers to handle loan payments, and even if they handled it all in house, they would have to pay employees to do that. If interest on the loans don't cover that expense, then the government is losing money.
